results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.headline_credit: Australia, Netherlands, Switzerland and Wales, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film depicts a trip to the Netherlands and Switzerland, beginning in Welshpool, Wales. It features scenes of “The Dingle” gardens, country fairs, folk dancing, show jumping in Welshpool, Dutch seaside, canal trips in the Netherlands, streetscapes, countryside, farm life, Rotterdam, Spannenburg, bus trip to the Alps, Switzerland, Brienz and Grindenwald.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:40:00 sign “The Dingle” of the Dingle Gardens
00:01:14:00 folk dancing at a country fair
00:02:10:00 horse jumping
00:02:51:00 Dutch seaside featuring people in lounge chairs
00:03:15:00 canal trip through countryside and urban area
00:04:11:00 farm life and creatures including a white peacock, and a young adult in fashionable clothing and clogs holding a skull
00:05:55:00 Commonwealth War Grave sign and cemetery
00:06:05:00 Spannenburg sign shot from a car
00:06:30:00 De Dude Are Museum sign and building shot from boat on a canal
00:07:29:00 in city, people gathering for the arrival of a celebrity
00:07:46:00 three people lining up to eat fish by holding tail up in the air above their heads, in sync
00:07:52:00 miniature theme park featuring tiny windmills, trams, boats, gardens, with one of the boats on fire
00:11:46:00 local market in Rotterdam, possibly; youth fashion
00:14:03:00 bus trip to Switzerland, featuring mountains and countryside scenes
00:16:02:00 feeding bears in a zoo
00:18:09:00 scene of large waterfall
00:20:13:00 Sinclair’s friends having a snowball fight
00:20:58:00 steam train

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This home movie shows the filmmaker and his wife travelling around England in a small yellow mini. They begin in London and travel across England to Stonehenge, up through the south of Scotland up to Loch Lomond and The Trossachs National Park, back to Edinburgh and end up in Blackpool.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:02:47:00 changing of the Guard
00:05:23:00 Stonehenge – brief look at Stonehenge
00:05:34:00 Stratford-Upon-Avon Cricket Club sign, walking through gardens and a spot of cricket
00:06:58:00 Shakespeare’s Birthplace Trust
00:09:17:00 road trip sign to Penrith, Carlisle and Kendal
00:10:17:00 Fferry trip – Windemere ferry, ’The Ferry House Windemere Laboratory of the Freshwater Biological Association Private Gardens’
00:13:15:00 Loch Lomond Sailings Ltd
00:14:42:00 the Elizabethan Inn – filmmaker and wife meet up with three other women at the inn
00:15:39:00 Tormore Distillery with friends – Long John Scotch Whiskey
00:16:56:00 father and two young girls feeding ducks at a lake
00:17:41:00 Roths Glen Hotel – mini donkeys and friends
00:19:11:00 sign to Pitlochry
00:19:45:00 castle or Military Fort in Edinburgh, guards in kilts
00:20:17:00 cemetery for soldier dogs
00:21:14:00 Blackpool

results.title: Bins vs. Rubbish [game trailer]
results.creator_credit: Auburn Primary School, Ari Kritzerseferi, Harry Dempsey, Jordan Trieu and Luc Thompson
results.brief_description:
A short excerpt from a computer game created for the 2010 ‘Screen It’ competition. This fun strategy game lets you dodge, catch and shoot rubbish. The message is to stop littering, as it can hurt animals and increase global warming.

This trailer illustrates how the game is played.

results.title: Future

results.brief_description: A boy walks through a beautiful, undisturbed world, then opens a door that unleashes human nature. What will happen? A symbolic and dark animation.

results.title: Turmoil [game trailer]
results.brief_description:
This challenging platform game takes place in the year 3000, amid environmental chaos. Your task is to deliver the final piece of a time machine that will allow scientists to travel to the past to introduce sustainable thinking practices.

This trailer illustrates how the game is played.

results.title: 'Screen It' 2010 [winning entries]
results.brief_description:
‘Screen It’ is Australia’s national film, animation and game making competition for school-aged students. Designed to encourage imagination and inventiveness in primary and secondary school students, ‘Screen It’ fosters a new generation of young media makers.

In 2010 students were asked to create works responding to the theme ‘The Environment: Who Cares?’.

From 256 entries created by over 939 students nationwide, here are the winners:

Primary - Animation
Winner: Control Your Carbondioxides, Carey Baptist Grammar Junior School (Kew, VIC)
Runners Up:
The Reason I Hate News Reporters: The Global Warming Quiz, Glencoe Central Primary School (Glencoe, SA)
Best Place Ever!, Cabramatta Public School (Cabramatta, NSW)
Curse of the Were-Rubbish, Léon Othenin-Girard (Balwyn North, VIC)
The Last Frog, Keller Road Primary School (Salisbury East, SA)
Wilhelmina Wiggins, Table Cape Primary School (Wynyard, TAS)
Supa Poopa Scoopa, Hernani Public School (Hernani, NSW)

Primary - Live Action
Winner: One World, Poowong Consolidated School (Poowong, VIC)
Special Mention: CRASH!, Cabramatta Public School (Cabramatta, NSW)
Runners Up:
Stop the Dumping! An Investigation into Illegal Dumping in Glencoe, South Australia, Glencoe Central Primary School (Glencoe, SA)
Duck Duck Turtle, Orama Public School (Thora, NSW)
Enviro - Planetary Defender, Rouse Hill Public School (Rouse Hill, NSW)

Primary - Computer Game
Winner: Bins vs. Rubbish, Auburn Primary School (East Hawthorn, VIC)
Special Mention: Cleaning Beezzz, Tea Tree Gully Primary School (Tea Tree Gully, SA)
Runners Up:
The Adventures of Seed Boy, Glencoe Central Primary School (Glencoe, SA)
The Adventures of Green Man, Marlborough Primary School (Heathmont, VIC)

Secondary - Animation
Winner: Future, Parramatta Marist High School (Westmead, NSW)
Special Mention: Not Just Us, Sarah Sloan (Princes Hill, VIC)
Runners Up:
Welcome to ‘R’ Ville, Selina Finau (Woodpark, NSW)
Think Climate, Think Change, Maryanne Irhia (Kensington, NSW)
The Environment. Who Cares?, Overnewton Anglican Community College (Keilor, VIC)
Who Cares?, Sasha Mutch (Ringwood, VIC)

Secondary - Live Action
Winner: Long Live the Can, Andreas Stoffel (Halls Gap, VIC)
Special Mention: ZombieBusters, Gleneagles Secondary College (Endeavour Hills, VIC)
Runners Up:
The Environment: Who Cares?, Loxton High School (Loxton, SA)
Behind Nature’s Lines, Parramatta Marist High School (Westmead, NSW)
One Person’s Perspective, St Ursula’s College (Toowoomba, QLD)

Secondary - Computer Game
Winner: Turmoil, Cameron Panzenbock (Ingham QLD)
Greenie’s Excellent Adventure, Connor Mosca (Caboolture, QLD)
Mr. Ooga Booga Saves the Forrest, Imogen Lee (Caboolture, QLD)
Mr. Octopus Saves the Sea and the Sky, Jesse Lee (Caboolture, QLD)
Park Ranger, Luke Holdsworth (Donvale, VIC)
Trash Pick Up!, Christoffel Roelofse (Donvale VIC)

description_for_label:
‘Screen It’ is Australia’s national film, animation and game making competition for school-aged students. Designed to encourage imagination and inventiveness in primary and secondary school students, ‘Screen It’ fosters a new generation of young media makers.

In 2010 students were asked to create works responding to the theme ‘The Environment: Who Cares?’.

From 256 entries created by over 939 students nationwide, here are the winners:

Primary - Animation
Winner: Control Your Carbondioxides, Carey Baptist Grammar Junior School (Kew, VIC)
Runners Up:
The Reason I Hate News Reporters: The Global Warming Quiz, Glencoe Central Primary School (Glencoe, SA)
Best Place Ever!, Cabramatta Public School (Cabramatta, NSW)
Curse of the Were-Rubbish, Léon Othenin-Girard (Balwyn North, VIC)
The Last Frog, Keller Road Primary School (Salisbury East, SA)
Wilhelmina Wiggins, Table Cape Primary School (Wynyard, TAS)
Supa Poopa Scoopa, Hernani Public School (Hernani, NSW)

Primary - Live Action
Winner: One World, Poowong Consolidated School (Poowong, VIC)
Special Mention: CRASH!, Cabramatta Public School (Cabramatta, NSW)
Runners Up:
Stop the Dumping! An Investigation into Illegal Dumping in Glencoe, South Australia, Glencoe Central Primary School (Glencoe, SA)
